2009/6/2 Jeff Clune <jclune@...>:
>
>
> Hello all-
>
> T=
here are frequently conversations on this list about what parameter
> setti=
ngs to use for evolutionary runs.
>
> At the CEC conference this year I saw=
 a presentation of a paper which
> reviews and compares different algorithm=
s for automating the
> setting of parameters for evolutionary algorithms. T=
hey report that the best
> algorithms for setting experimental parameters g=
reatly improve performance
> vs. humans picking their own values.
>
> It mi=
ght be interesting to turn the best in class algorithm loose on NEAT or
> H=
yperNEAT, and see what parameters are chosen (and then see how much these
>=
 results generalize to different problem domains). At a minimum, these
> al=
gorithms may help you if you are looking to truly optimize whatever
> probl=
em you are working on.
>
> Comparing Parameter Tuning Methods for Evolution=
ary Algorithms. Smit and
> Eiben. CEC 2009.
>
> Abstract:
> Tuning the para=
meters of an evolutionary algorithm (EA) to a given problem
> at hand is es=
sential for good algorithm performance. Optimizing parameter
> values is, h=
owever, a non-trivial problem, beyond the limits of human
> problem solving=
. In this light it is odd that no parameter tuning algorithms
> are used wi=
dely in evolutionary computing. This paper is meant to be
> stepping stone =
towards a better practice by discussing the most important
> issues related=
 to tuning EA parameters, describing a number of existing
> tuning methods,=
 and presenting a modest experimental comparison among them.
> The paper is=
 concluded by suggestions for future research =8B hopefully
> inspiring fel=
low researchers for further work
>
> PS. I can send you the paper if you em=
ail me.
>
> PPS. I talked to A. E. Eiben, one of the authors, about the fac=
t that
> automating
> the process seems on the surface to contradict my PLo=
S Computational Biology
> paper result that evolution is
> bad at managing =
its own parameters. While we had a very long chat about
> That result in ge=
neral, which I will not recount, the apparent contradiction
> is resolved w=
hen
> one realizes that here evolution is not managing its own parameters d=
uring
> the run, but only choosing good settings to have fixed throughout t=
he run.
>
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
>
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State =
University
>
> jclune@...
>
>
